general: This law makes sure that new buildings are built in an environmentally friendly way, using sustainable materials and energy-efficient systems. It also ensures that buildings are designed and constructed to be safe and secure for everyone who uses them. The goal of the act is to create healthier, more comfortable, and more secure buildings for people to live and work in.

series.short: Building Regulations Expanded to Protect Environment
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The purpose of building regulations is expanded to include furthering the conservation of fuel and power, preventing waste, and protecting the environment.
* Simplified point 2: The scope of building regulations is broadened to cover not only the design and construction of buildings but also the demolition of buildings and services, fittings, and equipment provided in or near buildings.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "substantive requirements" in the Act is updated to reflect these changes.

series.short: "Sustainable Building Regulations: Emphasis on Energy Efficiency and Security"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 amends the Building Act 1984 to include provisions related to sustainability and security in building regulations.
* Simplified point 2: The amendments allow for building regulations to apply to existing buildings when there is a change in occupancy, and require measures to be taken to reduce emissions of smoke, gases, vapors, and fumes.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can also require the use of recycled materials and the reuse of materials and components, and provide for the demolition of buildings.
* Simplified point 4: The Crown application of the regulations is extended to cover changes in occupants of buildings.

* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 allows for continuing requirements to be placed on building owners and occupants regarding the use of fuels, power, and emissions. These requirements can include inspections and testing of buildings and their systems, as well as the implementation of measures to reduce emissions.
* Simplified point 2: The Act gives local authorities the power to enforce these continuing requirements and imposes civil liability for non-compliance. It also applies to existing buildings, regardless of when they were built.

series.short: "Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 Removes Exemptions for Educational Buildings and Other Authorities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 removes certain exemptions from the Building Act 1984 that allowed educational buildings, buildings of statutory undertakers and other authorities, and licensees to not comply with some requirements of the Act.
* Simplified point 2: Specifically, sections 4 and 59(4) and (5) of the Building Act 1984 will no longer be in effect after the Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 takes effect.

series.short: "Building Regulation Reporting Requirements in England and Wales"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Secretary of State must prepare a report every two years on the progress of building regulations in England and Wales.
* Simplified point 2: The report must cover building regulations made or proposed during the period, their effects, and overall changes in energy efficiency and emissions.
* Simplified point 3: The report must include an estimate of the number of dwellings in England and Wales.
* Simplified point 4: The Secretary of State must lay the report before Parliament.

series.short: "Sustainable Building Regulations: Public Access to Information"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 requires local authorities to keep registers of information and documents related to building regulations.
* Simplified point 2: The registers must contain documents given or issued to the local authority, copies of documents, information about documents, and information about matters to which the documents relate.
* Simplified point 3: Local authorities must maintain the registers and make them available for public inspection during specified periods. They can also charge fees for providing copies of the information to the public.
* Simplified point 4: Regulations made under this section can provide for different provisions based on area or circumstance, and include transitional provisions for existing registers kept by local authorities.

* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 requires that certain professionals must issue certificates to local authorities or approved inspectors stating that building regulations have been met.
* Simplified point 2: These certificates can be used as evidence but are not conclusive proof of compliance.
* Simplified point 3: Local authorities and approved inspectors cannot exercise their powers without receiving these certificates or accepting them if they have been issued.
* Simplified point 4: The act also makes provisions for the acceptance of these certificates and other steps to be taken by local authorities or approved inspectors in connection with them.
* Simplified point 5: The act additionally covers offenses related to false or misleading certificates, including purporting to comply with requirements of the act or building regulations.

series.short: "Appointment and Oversight of Construction Works Under the Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 requires the appointment of a person (the "appointed person") to oversee and manage the carrying out of certain construction works.
* Simplified point 2: The appointed person must be a person of a prescribed class or description and must be appointed by a person determined in accordance with building regulations.
* Simplified point 3: Building regulations can specify the period within which the appointment must be made, and can also provide for the termination of the appointment and the replacement of the appointed person.
* Simplified point 4: The appointed person has duties in relation to the planning and management of the construction works, including ensuring compliance with building regulations, and can impose duties on other persons involved in the construction works.
* Simplified point 5: The duties imposed on other persons involved in the construction works include complying with directions given by the appointed person and adhering to determinations made by that person.

series.short: "UK Act Gives Secretary of State Power to Choose Effective Dates; Limited to England and Wales"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This act gives the power to the secretary of state to choose when certain parts of the act will go into effect.
* Simplified point 2: The act can be applied to only England and Wales.
* Simplified point 3: Certain sections of the act will automatically go into effect two months after it's passage.

series.short: "Sustainable Building Regulations: Improving Environmental Efficiency and Security"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 focuses on improving environmental sustainability through energy efficiency and reducing emissions.
* Simplified point 2: The Act expands the scope of building regulations to cover existing buildings and includes new provisions for sustainability and security.
* Simplified point 3: The Act gives local authorities the power to enforce continuing requirements related to emissions reduction and provides for reporting requirements and public access to information.
* Simplified point 4: The Act requires the appointment of an appointed person to oversee and manage certain construction works and gives the Secretary of State the power to choose effective dates.

summary: The Sustainable and Secure Buildings Act 2004 focuses on improving environmental sustainability and reducing carbon emissions through building regulations. Key provisions include expanding the scope of building regulations to cover more aspects of building design and construction, updating the definition of "substantive requirements," and requiring continued compliance with emissions reduction measures. Additionally, the act provides for enforcement mechanisms such as inspections and testing, and extends the application of regulations to existing buildings. The act also includes reporting requirements and public access to information, as well as specific provisions for educational buildings and other authorities. Finally, the act grants the Secretary of State the power to choose effective dates and limits its application to only England and Wales.
